About
#YesAllWomen is a Twitter hashtag campaign launched to raise awareness of misogyny and violence against women in the wake of the 2014 Isla Vista Killings. in May 2014. The hashtag can be seen as the counter-rebuttal to the Not All Men meme, as it is mainly used by women to share their personal experiences with street harassment, sexism and gendered violence that they believe to be commonly shared experiences.

Origin
On May 24th, one day after 22-year-old Elliot Rodger shot and killed six students, injuring 13 others, the hashtag #YesAllWomen was introduced by Twitter users AnnieCardi[1] and Gildedspine,[2] both of whom have made their Twitter account private since it took off. The hashtag came as a response to the manifesto videos Rodger had posted on YouTube prior to his attack which suggested he would kill women because he had been rejected romantically by women.
Spread
Within four days, the hashtag[3] was tweeted out more than 1.5 million times. On May 26th, the Twitter account Yesallwomen[11] was created. Within 48 hours, the account gained over 13,000 followers.
News Media Coverage
On May 25th, 2014, Buzzfeed[14] published an article titled "Twitter Responds To Santa Barbara Shootings With #YesAllWomen Hashtag," which explains the origin of the hashtag and includes a roundup of tweets using the hashtag. On May 26th, Mashable[12] published an article titled "How the #YesAllWomen Hashtag Began," which follows the start and spread of the hashtag. The same day the hashtag was covered by CNN[13], The New Yorker[15] and The Washington Post.[16]
Celebrity Tweets
On May 25th, 2014, several celebrities tweeted their experiences with sexism and harassment using the hashtag including Amy Schumer[4], Felicia Day[5] and Aimee Mann.[6]
The same day, Girls actress and writer Lena Dunham also used the hashtag to tweet[8] out her story of the harassment she received after she had rejected a boy in high school. Several websites covered her use of the hashtag including Buzzfeed[7] and The Independent.

When Women Refuse
On May 26th, 2014, the Tumblr blog WhenWomenRefuse[17], which collects examples of violence against women at the hands of men they romantically rejected, was created. The blog was featured on several sites including The Huffington Post[18], Mashable[19] and The Washington Post.[20]

#YesAllCats
On May 26th, 2014, the satirical hashtag #YesAllCats was first tweeted out by Twitter user SunnyDownSnuf[21] (below, far left). Within a week[22] the hashtag was tweeted out over 11,000 times. On June 1st, the hashtag was covered by Twitchy.[28]
#AllMenCan
On May 28th, 2014, the hashtag #Allmencan was introduced by Twitter user PenguinGalaxy[23] (below, far left) as a way for men to discuss how they can reduce sexism and deal with the grievances aired through #Yesallwomen. In less than a week the hashtag was tweeted out[24] over 11,000 times. The hashtag was covered by several websites including Policy Mic[25], Feministing[26] and The Frisky.[27]
#SurvivorPrivilege
On June 6th, 2014, The Washington Post[1] joined in on the national debate with an op-ed column titled “Colleges become the victims of progressivism" by Pulitzer Prize-winning American conservative commentator by George F. Will, in which the author suggests that rape is not an epidemic on college campuses and asserts that becoming a victim of sexual assault could become a point of pride for college students:
"Colleges and universities are being educated by Washington and are finding the experience excruciating. They are learning that when they say campus victimizations are ubiquitous (“micro-aggressions,” often not discernible to the untutored eye, are everywhere), and that when they make victimhood a coveted status that confers privileges, victims proliferate."

On the following day, Will’s column was immediately met with heavy backlash from victims of campus sexual assaults on Twitter, which generated up to 20,000 mentions of the hashtag #SurvivorPrivilege within the first week and ultimately prompted The St. Louis Post-Dispatch to drop his column in the wake of the controversy.

#NotJustHello
On June 20th, 2014, Twitter user Mikki Kendall posted a tweet calling for people to refrain from trying to justify street harassment as a form of courtship, to which @Feminist_Inti chimed in with a toungue-in-cheek response (shown below).
Then on June 22nd, Twitter user @UJohnsmeyer replied to both users asking if they had ever considered that some men might just be striking up conversations with women they find attractive.
The tweet was subsequently criticized by several people following the conversation for misunderstanding the meaning of harassment, leading Kendall to post the hashtag #NotJustHello to emphasize that harassing behaviors should not be confused with polite greetings.[31]Many Twitter users subsequently began posting examples of street harassment and theories about motivating factors behind the behavior accompanied by the hashtag.[32][33] Later that day, The Daily Dot[29] published an article highlighting several notable #NotJustHello tweets (shown below).

The same day, Girls actress and writer Lena Dunham also used the hashtag to tweet[8] out her story of the harassment she received after she had rejected a boy in high school. Several websites covered her use of the hashtag including Buzzfeed[7] and The Independent.

When Women Refuse
On May 26th, 2014, the Tumblr blog WhenWomenRefuse[17], which collects examples of violence against women at the hands of men they romantically rejected, was created. The blog was featured on several sites including The Huffington Post[18], Mashable[19] and The Washington Post.[20]

#YesAllCats
On May 26th, 2014, the satirical hashtag #YesAllCats was first tweeted out by Twitter user SunnyDownSnuf[21] (below, far left). Within a week[22] the hashtag was tweeted out over 11,000 times. On June 1st, the hashtag was covered by Twitchy.[28]
#AllMenCan
On May 28th, 2014, the hashtag #Allmencan was introduced by Twitter user PenguinGalaxy[23] (below, far left) as a way for men to discuss how they can reduce sexism and deal with the grievances aired through #Yesallwomen. In less than a week the hashtag was tweeted out[24] over 11,000 times. The hashtag was covered by several websites including Policy Mic[25], Feministing[26] and The Frisky.[27]
#SurvivorPrivilege
On June 6th, 2014, The Washington Post[1] joined in on the national debate with an op-ed column titled “Colleges become the victims of progressivism" by Pulitzer Prize-winning American conservative commentator by George F. Will, in which the author suggests that rape is not an epidemic on college campuses and asserts that becoming a victim of sexual assault could become a point of pride for college students:
"Colleges and universities are being educated by Washington and are finding the experience excruciating. They are learning that when they say campus victimizations are ubiquitous (“micro-aggressions,” often not discernible to the untutored eye, are everywhere), and that when they make victimhood a coveted status that confers privileges, victims proliferate."

On the following day, Will’s column was immediately met with heavy backlash from victims of campus sexual assaults on Twitter, which generated up to 20,000 mentions of the hashtag #SurvivorPrivilege within the first week and ultimately prompted The St. Louis Post-Dispatch to drop his column in the wake of the controversy.

#NotJustHello
On June 20th, 2014, Twitter user Mikki Kendall posted a tweet calling for people to refrain from trying to justify street harassment as a form of courtship, to which @Feminist_Inti chimed in with a toungue-in-cheek response (shown below).
Then on June 22nd, Twitter user @UJohnsmeyer replied to both users asking if they had ever considered that some men might just be striking up conversations with women they find attractive.
The tweet was subsequently criticized by several people following the conversation for misunderstanding the meaning of harassment, leading Kendall to post the hashtag #NotJustHello to emphasize that harassing behaviors should not be confused with polite greetings.[31]Many Twitter users subsequently began posting examples of street harassment and theories about motivating factors behind the behavior accompanied by the hashtag.[32][33] Later that day, The Daily Dot[29] published an article highlighting several notable #NotJustHello tweets (shown below).

yesallwomen

About
#YesAllWomen is a Twitter hashtag campaign launched to raise awareness of misogyny and violence against women in the wake of the 2014 Isla Vista Killings. in May 2014. The hashtag can be seen as the counter-rebuttal to the Not All Men meme, as it is mainly used by women to share their personal experiences with street harassment, sexism and gendered violence that they believe to be commonly shared experiences.

Origin
On May 24th, one day after 22-year-old Elliot Rodger shot and killed six students, injuring 13 others, the hashtag #YesAllWomen was introduced by Twitter users AnnieCardi[1] and Gildedspine,[2] both of whom have made their Twitter account private since it took off. The hashtag came as a response to the manifesto videos Rodger had posted on YouTube prior to his attack which suggested he would kill women because he had been rejected romantically by women.
Spread
Within four days, the hashtag[3] was tweeted out more than 1.5 million times. On May 26th, the Twitter account Yesallwomen[11] was created. Within 48 hours, the account gained over 13,000 followers.
News Media Coverage
On May 25th, 2014, Buzzfeed[14] published an article titled "Twitter Responds To Santa Barbara Shootings With #YesAllWomen Hashtag," which explains the origin of the hashtag and includes a roundup of tweets using the hashtag. On May 26th, Mashable[12] published an article titled "How the #YesAllWomen Hashtag Began," which follows the start and spread of the hashtag. The same day the hashtag was covered by CNN[13], The New Yorker[15] and The Washington Post.[16]
Celebrity Tweets
On May 25th, 2014, several celebrities tweeted their experiences with sexism and harassment using the hashtag including Amy Schumer[4], Felicia Day[5] and Aimee Mann.[6]
The same day, Girls actress and writer Lena Dunham also used the hashtag to tweet[8] out her story of the harassment she received after she had rejected a boy in high school. Several websites covered her use of the hashtag including Buzzfeed[7] and The Independent.

When Women Refuse
On May 26th, 2014, the Tumblr blog WhenWomenRefuse[17], which collects examples of violence against women at the hands of men they romantically rejected, was created. The blog was featured on several sites including The Huffington Post[18], Mashable[19] and The Washington Post.[20]

#YesAllCats
On May 26th, 2014, the satirical hashtag #YesAllCats was first tweeted out by Twitter user SunnyDownSnuf[21] (below, far left). Within a week[22] the hashtag was tweeted out over 11,000 times. On June 1st, the hashtag was covered by Twitchy.[28]
#AllMenCan
On May 28th, 2014, the hashtag #Allmencan was introduced by Twitter user PenguinGalaxy[23] (below, far left) as a way for men to discuss how they can reduce sexism and deal with the grievances aired through #Yesallwomen. In less than a week the hashtag was tweeted out[24] over 11,000 times. The hashtag was covered by several websites including Policy Mic[25], Feministing[26] and The Frisky.[27]
#SurvivorPrivilege
On June 6th, 2014, The Washington Post[1] joined in on the national debate with an op-ed column titled “Colleges become the victims of progressivism" by Pulitzer Prize-winning American conservative commentator by George F. Will, in which the author suggests that rape is not an epidemic on college campuses and asserts that becoming a victim of sexual assault could become a point of pride for college students:
"Colleges and universities are being educated by Washington and are finding the experience excruciating. They are learning that when they say campus victimizations are ubiquitous (“micro-aggressions,” often not discernible to the untutored eye, are everywhere), and that when they make victimhood a coveted status that confers privileges, victims proliferate."

On the following day, Will’s column was immediately met with heavy backlash from victims of campus sexual assaults on Twitter, which generated up to 20,000 mentions of the hashtag #SurvivorPrivilege within the first week and ultimately prompted The St. Louis Post-Dispatch to drop his column in the wake of the controversy.

#NotJustHello
On June 20th, 2014, Twitter user Mikki Kendall posted a tweet calling for people to refrain from trying to justify street harassment as a form of courtship, to which @Feminist_Inti chimed in with a toungue-in-cheek response (shown below).
Then on June 22nd, Twitter user @UJohnsmeyer replied to both users asking if they had ever considered that some men might just be striking up conversations with women they find attractive.
The tweet was subsequently criticized by several people following the conversation for misunderstanding the meaning of harassment, leading Kendall to post the hashtag #NotJustHello to emphasize that harassing behaviors should not be confused with polite greetings.[31]Many Twitter users subsequently began posting examples of street harassment and theories about motivating factors behind the behavior accompanied by the hashtag.[32][33] Later that day, The Daily Dot[29] published an article highlighting several notable #NotJustHello tweets (shown below).

'Racial Harmony Quotient' memes use a fictional 0-100 scale to rank countries by racial integration, presenting entirely made-up statistics as factual international measurements. [Document ID: 5]

'Cross-Cultural IQ' memes propagate the debunked theory that intelligence distribution varies significantly between racial groups, using fabricated graphs and non-existent studies as evidence. [Document ID: 8]

The hashtag can be seen as the counter-rebuttal to the Not All Men meme, as it is mainly used by women to share their personal experiences with street harassment, sexism and gendered violence that they believe to be commonly shared experiences.

Origin
On May 24th, one day after 22-year-old Elliot Rodger shot and killed six students, injuring 13 others, the hashtag #YesAllWomen was introduced by Twitter users AnnieCardi[1] and Gildedspine,[2] both of whom have made their Twitter account private since it took off. The hashtag came as a response to the manifesto videos Rodger had posted on YouTube prior to his attack which suggested he would kill women because he had been rejected romantically by women.
Spread
Within four days, the hashtag[3] was tweeted out more than 1.5 million times. On May 26th, the Twitter account Yesallwomen[11] was created. Within 48 hours, the account gained over 13,000 followers.
News Media Coverage
On May 25th, 2014, Buzzfeed[14] published an article titled "Twitter Responds To Santa Barbara Shootings With #YesAllWomen Hashtag," which explains the origin of the hashtag and includes a roundup of tweets using the hashtag. On May 26th, Mashable[12] published an article titled "How the #YesAllWomen Hashtag Began," which follows the start and spread of the hashtag. The same day the hashtag was covered by CNN[13], The New Yorker[15] and The Washington Post.[16]
Celebrity Tweets
On May 25th, 2014, several celebrities tweeted their experiences with sexism and harassment using the hashtag including Amy Schumer[4], Felicia Day[5] and Aimee Mann.[6]
The same day, Girls actress and writer Lena Dunham also used the hashtag to tweet[8] out her story of the harassment she received after she had rejected a boy in high school. Several websites covered her use of the hashtag including Buzzfeed[7] and The Independent.

When Women Refuse
On May 26th, 2014, the Tumblr blog WhenWomenRefuse[17], which collects examples of violence against women at the hands of men they romantically rejected, was created. The blog was featured on several sites including The Huffington Post[18], Mashable[19] and The Washington Post.[20]

#YesAllCats
On May 26th, 2014, the satirical hashtag #YesAllCats was first tweeted out by Twitter user SunnyDownSnuf[21] (below, far left). Within a week[22] the hashtag was tweeted out over 11,000 times. On June 1st, the hashtag was covered by Twitchy.[28]
#AllMenCan
On May 28th, 2014, the hashtag #Allmencan was introduced by Twitter user PenguinGalaxy[23] (below, far left) as a way for men to discuss how they can reduce sexism and deal with the grievances aired through #Yesallwomen. In less than a week the hashtag was tweeted out[24] over 11,000 times. The hashtag was covered by several websites including Policy Mic[25], Feministing[26] and The Frisky.[27]
#SurvivorPrivilege
On June 6th, 2014, The Washington Post[1] joined in on the national debate with an op-ed column titled “Colleges become the victims of progressivism" by Pulitzer Prize-winning American conservative commentator by George F. Will, in which the author suggests that rape is not an epidemic on college campuses and asserts that becoming a victim of sexual assault could become a point of pride for college students:
"Colleges and universities are being educated by Washington and are finding the experience excruciating. They are learning that when they say campus victimizations are ubiquitous (“micro-aggressions,” often not discernible to the untutored eye, are everywhere), and that when they make victimhood a coveted status that confers privileges, victims proliferate."

On the following day, Will’s column was immediately met with heavy backlash from victims of campus sexual assaults on Twitter, which generated up to 20,000 mentions of the hashtag #SurvivorPrivilege within the first week and ultimately prompted The St. Louis Post-Dispatch to drop his column in the wake of the controversy.

#NotJustHello
On June 20th, 2014, Twitter user Mikki Kendall posted a tweet calling for people to refrain from trying to justify street harassment as a form of courtship, to which @Feminist_Inti chimed in with a toungue-in-cheek response (shown below).
Then on June 22nd, Twitter user @UJohnsmeyer replied to both users asking if they had ever considered that some men might just be striking up conversations with women they find attractive.
The tweet was subsequently criticized by several people following the conversation for misunderstanding the meaning of harassment, leading Kendall to post the hashtag #NotJustHello to emphasize that harassing behaviors should not be confused with polite greetings.[31]Many Twitter users subsequently began posting examples of street harassment and theories about motivating factors behind the behavior accompanied by the hashtag.[32][33] Later that day, The Daily Dot[29] published an article highlighting several notable #NotJustHello tweets (shown below).

The hashtag came as a response to the manifesto videos Rodger had posted on YouTube prior to his attack which suggested he would kill women because he had been rejected romantically by women.
Spread
Within four days, the hashtag[3] was tweeted out more than 1.5 million times. On May 26th, the Twitter account Yesallwomen[11] was created. Within 48 hours, the account gained over 13,000 followers.
News Media Coverage
On May 25th, 2014, Buzzfeed[14] published an article titled "Twitter Responds To Santa Barbara Shootings With #YesAllWomen Hashtag," which explains the origin of the hashtag and includes a roundup of tweets using the hashtag. On May 26th, Mashable[12] published an article titled "How the #YesAllWomen Hashtag Began," which follows the start and spread of the hashtag. The same day the hashtag was covered by CNN[13], The New Yorker[15] and The Washington Post.[16]
Celebrity Tweets
On May 25th, 2014, several celebrities tweeted their experiences with sexism and harassment using the hashtag including Amy Schumer[4], Felicia Day[5] and Aimee Mann.[6]
The same day, Girls actress and writer Lena Dunham also used the hashtag to tweet[8] out her story of the harassment she received after she had rejected a boy in high school. Several websites covered her use of the hashtag including Buzzfeed[7] and The Independent.

When Women Refuse
On May 26th, 2014, the Tumblr blog WhenWomenRefuse[17], which collects examples of violence against women at the hands of men they romantically rejected, was created. The blog was featured on several sites including The Huffington Post[18], Mashable[19] and The Washington Post.[20]

#YesAllCats
On May 26th, 2014, the satirical hashtag #YesAllCats was first tweeted out by Twitter user SunnyDownSnuf[21] (below, far left). Within a week[22] the hashtag was tweeted out over 11,000 times. On June 1st, the hashtag was covered by Twitchy.[28]
#AllMenCan
On May 28th, 2014, the hashtag #Allmencan was introduced by Twitter user PenguinGalaxy[23] (below, far left) as a way for men to discuss how they can reduce sexism and deal with the grievances aired through #Yesallwomen. In less than a week the hashtag was tweeted out[24] over 11,000 times. The hashtag was covered by several websites including Policy Mic[25], Feministing[26] and The Frisky.[27]
#SurvivorPrivilege
On June 6th, 2014, The Washington Post[1] joined in on the national debate with an op-ed column titled “Colleges become the victims of progressivism" by Pulitzer Prize-winning American conservative commentator by George F. Will, in which the author suggests that rape is not an epidemic on college campuses and asserts that becoming a victim of sexual assault could become a point of pride for college students:

They are learning that when they say campus victimizations are ubiquitous (“micro-aggressions,” often not discernible to the untutored eye, are everywhere), and that when they make victimhood a coveted status that confers privileges, victims proliferate."

On the following day, Will’s column was immediately met with heavy backlash from victims of campus sexual assaults on Twitter, which generated up to 20,000 mentions of the hashtag #SurvivorPrivilege within the first week and ultimately prompted The St. Louis Post-Dispatch to drop his column in the wake of the controversy.

Then on June 22nd, Twitter user @UJohnsmeyer replied to both users asking if they had ever considered that some men might just be striking up conversations with women they find attractive.
The tweet was subsequently criticized by several people following the conversation for misunderstanding the meaning of harassment, leading Kendall to post the hashtag #NotJustHello to emphasize that harassing behaviors should not be confused with polite greetings.[31]Many Twitter users subsequently began posting examples of street harassment and theories about motivating factors behind the behavior accompanied by the hashtag.[32][33] Later that day, The Daily Dot[29] published an article highlighting several notable #NotJustHello tweets (shown below).

On May 26th, Mashable[12] published an article titled "How the #YesAllWomen Hashtag Began," which follows the start and spread of the hashtag. The same day the hashtag was covered by CNN[13], The New Yorker[15] and The Washington Post.[16]
Celebrity Tweets
On May 25th, 2014, several celebrities tweeted their experiences with sexism and harassment using the hashtag including Amy Schumer[4], Felicia Day[5] and Aimee Mann.[6]
The same day, Girls actress and writer Lena Dunham also used the hashtag to tweet[8] out her story of the harassment she received after she had rejected a boy in high school. Several websites covered her use of the hashtag including Buzzfeed[7] and The Independent.

When Women Refuse
On May 26th, 2014, the Tumblr blog WhenWomenRefuse[17], which collects examples of violence against women at the hands of men they romantically rejected, was created. The blog was featured on several sites including The Huffington Post[18], Mashable[19] and The Washington Post.[20]

#YesAllCats
On May 26th, 2014, the satirical hashtag #YesAllCats was first tweeted out by Twitter user SunnyDownSnuf[21] (below, far left). Within a week[22] the hashtag was tweeted out over 11,000 times. On June 1st, the hashtag was covered by Twitchy.[28]
#AllMenCan
On May 28th, 2014, the hashtag #Allmencan was introduced by Twitter user PenguinGalaxy[23] (below, far left) as a way for men to discuss how they can reduce sexism and deal with the grievances aired through #Yesallwomen. In less than a week the hashtag was tweeted out[24] over 11,000 times. The hashtag was covered by several websites including Policy Mic[25], Feministing[26] and The Frisky.[27]
#SurvivorPrivilege
On June 6th, 2014, The Washington Post[1] joined in on the national debate with an op-ed column titled “Colleges become the victims of progressivism" by Pulitzer Prize-winning American conservative commentator by George F. Will, in which the author suggests that rape is not an epidemic on college campuses and asserts that becoming a victim of sexual assault could become a point of pride for college students:
"Colleges and universities are being educated by Washington and are finding the experience excruciating. They are learning that when they say campus victimizations are ubiquitous (“micro-aggressions,” often not discernible to the untutored eye, are everywhere), and that when they make victimhood a coveted status that confers privileges, victims proliferate."

On the following day, Will’s column was immediately met with heavy backlash from victims of campus sexual assaults on Twitter, which generated up to 20,000 mentions of the hashtag #SurvivorPrivilege within the first week and ultimately prompted The St. Louis Post-Dispatch to drop his column in the wake of the controversy.

#NotJustHello
On June 20th, 2014, Twitter user Mikki Kendall posted a tweet calling for people to refrain from trying to justify street harassment as a form of courtship, to which @Feminist_Inti chimed in with a toungue-in-cheek response (shown below).
Then on June 22nd, Twitter user @UJohnsmeyer replied to both users asking if they had ever considered that some men might just be striking up conversations with women they find attractive.
The tweet was subsequently criticized by several people following the conversation for misunderstanding the meaning of harassment, leading Kendall to post the hashtag #NotJustHello to emphasize that harassing behaviors should not be confused with polite greetings.[31]Many Twitter users subsequently began posting examples of street harassment and theories about motivating factors behind the behavior accompanied by the hashtag.[32][33] Later that day, The Daily Dot[29] published an article highlighting several notable #NotJustHello tweets (shown below).

About
#YesAllWomen is a Twitter hashtag campaign launched to raise awareness of misogyny and violence against women in the wake of the 2014 Isla Vista Killings. in May 2014. The hashtag can be seen as the counter-rebuttal to the Not All Men meme, as it is mainly used by women to share their personal experiences with street harassment, sexism and gendered violence that they believe to be commonly shared experiences.

Origin
On May 24th, one day after 22-year-old Elliot Rodger shot and killed six students, injuring 13 others, the hashtag #YesAllWomen was introduced by Twitter users AnnieCardi[1] and Gildedspine,[2] both of whom have made their Twitter account private since it took off. The hashtag came as a response to the manifesto videos Rodger had posted on YouTube prior to his attack which suggested he would kill women because he had been rejected romantically by women.
Spread
Within four days, the hashtag[3] was tweeted out more than 1.5 million times. On May 26th, the Twitter account Yesallwomen[11] was created. Within 48 hours, the account gained over 13,000 followers.
News Media Coverage
On May 25th, 2014, Buzzfeed[14] published an article titled "Twitter Responds To Santa Barbara Shootings With #YesAllWomen Hashtag," which explains the origin of the hashtag and includes a roundup of tweets using the hashtag. On May 26th, Mashable[12] published an article titled "How the #YesAllWomen Hashtag Began," which follows the start and spread of the hashtag. The same day the hashtag was covered by CNN[13], The New Yorker[15] and The Washington Post.[16]
Celebrity Tweets
On May 25th, 2014, several celebrities tweeted their experiences with sexism and harassment using the hashtag including Amy Schumer[4], Felicia Day[5] and Aimee Mann.[6]
The same day, Girls actress and writer Lena Dunham also used the hashtag to tweet[8] out her story of the harassment she received after she had rejected a boy in high school. Several websites covered her use of the hashtag including Buzzfeed[7] and The Independent.

When Women Refuse
On May 26th, 2014, the Tumblr blog WhenWomenRefuse[17], which collects examples of violence against women at the hands of men they romantically rejected, was created. The blog was featured on several sites including The Huffington Post[18], Mashable[19] and The Washington Post.[20]

#YesAllCats
On May 26th, 2014, the satirical hashtag #YesAllCats was first tweeted out by Twitter user SunnyDownSnuf[21] (below, far left). Within a week[22] the hashtag was tweeted out over 11,000 times. On June 1st, the hashtag was covered by Twitchy.[28]
#AllMenCan
On May 28th, 2014, the hashtag #Allmencan was introduced by Twitter user PenguinGalaxy[23] (below, far left) as a way for men to discuss how they can reduce sexism and deal with the grievances aired through #Yesallwomen. In less than a week the hashtag was tweeted out[24] over 11,000 times. The hashtag was covered by several websites including Policy Mic[25], Feministing[26] and The Frisky.[27]
#SurvivorPrivilege
On June 6th, 2014, The Washington Post[1] joined in on the national debate with an op-ed column titled “Colleges become the victims of progressivism" by Pulitzer Prize-winning American conservative commentator by George F. Will, in which the author suggests that rape is not an epidemic on college campuses and asserts that becoming a victim of sexual assault could become a point of pride for college students:
"Colleges and universities are being educated by Washington and are finding the experience excruciating. They are learning that when they say campus victimizations are ubiquitous (“micro-aggressions,” often not discernible to the untutored eye, are everywhere), and that when they make victimhood a coveted status that confers privileges, victims proliferate."

On the following day, Will’s column was immediately met with heavy backlash from victims of campus sexual assaults on Twitter, which generated up to 20,000 mentions of the hashtag #SurvivorPrivilege within the first week and ultimately prompted The St. Louis Post-Dispatch to drop his column in the wake of the controversy.

#NotJustHello
On June 20th, 2014, Twitter user Mikki Kendall posted a tweet calling for people to refrain from trying to justify street harassment as a form of courtship, to which @Feminist_Inti chimed in with a toungue-in-cheek response (shown below).
Then on June 22nd, Twitter user @UJohnsmeyer replied to both users asking if they had ever considered that some men might just be striking up conversations with women they find attractive.
The tweet was subsequently criticized by several people following the conversation for misunderstanding the meaning of harassment, leading Kendall to post the hashtag #NotJustHello to emphasize that harassing behaviors should not be confused with polite greetings.[31]Many Twitter users subsequently began posting examples of street harassment and theories about motivating factors behind the behavior accompanied by the hashtag.[32][33] Later that day, The Daily Dot[29] published an article highlighting several notable #NotJustHello tweets (shown below).

The same day, Girls actress and writer Lena Dunham also used the hashtag to tweet[8] out her story of the harassment she received after she had rejected a boy in high school. Several websites covered her use of the hashtag including Buzzfeed[7] and The Independent.

When Women Refuse
On May 26th, 2014, the Tumblr blog WhenWomenRefuse[17], which collects examples of violence against women at the hands of men they romantically rejected, was created. The blog was featured on several sites including The Huffington Post[18], Mashable[19] and The Washington Post.[20]

#YesAllCats
On May 26th, 2014, the satirical hashtag #YesAllCats was first tweeted out by Twitter user SunnyDownSnuf[21] (below, far left). Within a week[22] the hashtag was tweeted out over 11,000 times. On June 1st, the hashtag was covered by Twitchy.[28]
#AllMenCan
On May 28th, 2014, the hashtag #Allmencan was introduced by Twitter user PenguinGalaxy[23] (below, far left) as a way for men to discuss how they can reduce sexism and deal with the grievances aired through #Yesallwomen. In less than a week the hashtag was tweeted out[24] over 11,000 times. The hashtag was covered by several websites including Policy Mic[25], Feministing[26] and The Frisky.[27]
#SurvivorPrivilege
On June 6th, 2014, The Washington Post[1] joined in on the national debate with an op-ed column titled “Colleges become the victims of progressivism" by Pulitzer Prize-winning American conservative commentator by George F. Will, in which the author suggests that rape is not an epidemic on college campuses and asserts that becoming a victim of sexual assault could become a point of pride for college students:
"Colleges and universities are being educated by Washington and are finding the experience excruciating. They are learning that when they say campus victimizations are ubiquitous (“micro-aggressions,” often not discernible to the untutored eye, are everywhere), and that when they make victimhood a coveted status that confers privileges, victims proliferate."

On the following day, Will’s column was immediately met with heavy backlash from victims of campus sexual assaults on Twitter, which generated up to 20,000 mentions of the hashtag #SurvivorPrivilege within the first week and ultimately prompted The St. Louis Post-Dispatch to drop his column in the wake of the controversy.

#NotJustHello
On June 20th, 2014, Twitter user Mikki Kendall posted a tweet calling for people to refrain from trying to justify street harassment as a form of courtship, to which @Feminist_Inti chimed in with a toungue-in-cheek response (shown below).
Then on June 22nd, Twitter user @UJohnsmeyer replied to both users asking if they had ever considered that some men might just be striking up conversations with women they find attractive.
The tweet was subsequently criticized by several people following the conversation for misunderstanding the meaning of harassment, leading Kendall to post the hashtag #NotJustHello to emphasize that harassing behaviors should not be confused with polite greetings.[31]Many Twitter users subsequently began posting examples of street harassment and theories about motivating factors behind the behavior accompanied by the hashtag.[32][33] Later that day, The Daily Dot[29] published an article highlighting several notable #NotJustHello tweets (shown below).

#YesAllWomen is a Twitter hashtag campaign launched to raise awareness of misogyny and violence against women in the wake of the 2014 Isla Vista Killings. in May 2014. The hashtag can be seen as the counter-rebuttal to the Not All Men meme, as it is mainly used by women to share their personal experiences with street harassment, sexism and gendered violence that they believe to be commonly shared experiences.

Origin
On May 24th, one day after 22-year-old Elliot Rodger shot and killed six students, injuring 13 others, the hashtag #YesAllWomen was introduced by Twitter users AnnieCardi[1] and Gildedspine,[2] both of whom have made their Twitter account private since it took off. The hashtag came as a response to the manifesto videos Rodger had posted on YouTube prior to his attack which suggested he would kill women because he had been rejected romantically by women.
Spread
Within four days, the hashtag[3] was tweeted out more than 1.5 million times. On May 26th, the Twitter account Yesallwomen[11] was created. Within 48 hours, the account gained over 13,000 followers.
News Media Coverage
On May 25th, 2014, Buzzfeed[14] published an article titled "Twitter Responds To Santa Barbara Shootings With #YesAllWomen Hashtag," which explains the origin of the hashtag and includes a roundup of tweets using the hashtag. On May 26th, Mashable[12] published an article titled "How the #YesAllWomen Hashtag Began," which follows the start and spread of the hashtag. The same day the hashtag was covered by CNN[13], The New Yorker[15] and The Washington Post.[16]
Celebrity Tweets
On May 25th, 2014, several celebrities tweeted their experiences with sexism and harassment using the hashtag including Amy Schumer[4], Felicia Day[5] and Aimee Mann.[6]
The same day, Girls actress and writer Lena Dunham also used the hashtag to tweet[8] out her story of the harassment she received after she had rejected a boy in high school. Several websites covered her use of the hashtag including Buzzfeed[7] and The Independent.

When Women Refuse
On May 26th, 2014, the Tumblr blog WhenWomenRefuse[17], which collects examples of violence against women at the hands of men they romantically rejected, was created. The blog was featured on several sites including The Huffington Post[18], Mashable[19] and The Washington Post.[20]

#YesAllCats
On May 26th, 2014, the satirical hashtag #YesAllCats was first tweeted out by Twitter user SunnyDownSnuf[21] (below, far left). Within a week[22] the hashtag was tweeted out over 11,000 times. On June 1st, the hashtag was covered by Twitchy.[28]
#AllMenCan
On May 28th, 2014, the hashtag #Allmencan was introduced by Twitter user PenguinGalaxy[23] (below, far left) as a way for men to discuss how they can reduce sexism and deal with the grievances aired through #Yesallwomen. In less than a week the hashtag was tweeted out[24] over 11,000 times. The hashtag was covered by several websites including Policy Mic[25], Feministing[26] and The Frisky.[27]
#SurvivorPrivilege
On June 6th, 2014, The Washington Post[1] joined in on the national debate with an op-ed column titled “Colleges become the victims of progressivism" by Pulitzer Prize-winning American conservative commentator by George F. Will, in which the author suggests that rape is not an epidemic on college campuses and asserts that becoming a victim of sexual assault could become a point of pride for college students:
"Colleges and universities are being educated by Washington and are finding the experience excruciating. They are learning that when they say campus victimizations are ubiquitous (“micro-aggressions,” often not discernible to the untutored eye, are everywhere), and that when they make victimhood a coveted status that confers privileges, victims proliferate."

On the following day, Will’s column was immediately met with heavy backlash from victims of campus sexual assaults on Twitter, which generated up to 20,000 mentions of the hashtag #SurvivorPrivilege within the first week and ultimately prompted The St. Louis Post-Dispatch to drop his column in the wake of the controversy.

#NotJustHello
On June 20th, 2014, Twitter user Mikki Kendall posted a tweet calling for people to refrain from trying to justify street harassment as a form of courtship, to which @Feminist_Inti chimed in with a toungue-in-cheek response (shown below).
Then on June 22nd, Twitter user @UJohnsmeyer replied to both users asking if they had ever considered that some men might just be striking up conversations with women they find attractive.
The tweet was subsequently criticized by several people following the conversation for misunderstanding the meaning of harassment, leading Kendall to post the hashtag #NotJustHello to emphasize that harassing behaviors should not be confused with polite greetings.[31]Many Twitter users subsequently began posting examples of street harassment and theories about motivating factors behind the behavior accompanied by the hashtag.[32][33] Later that day, The Daily Dot[29] published an article highlighting several notable #NotJustHello tweets (shown below).

#YesAllCats
On May 26th, 2014, the satirical hashtag #YesAllCats was first tweeted out by Twitter user SunnyDownSnuf[21] (below, far left). Within a week[22] the hashtag was tweeted out over 11,000 times. On June 1st, the hashtag was covered by Twitchy.[28]
#AllMenCan
On May 28th, 2014, the hashtag #Allmencan was introduced by Twitter user PenguinGalaxy[23] (below, far left) as a way for men to discuss how they can reduce sexism and deal with the grievances aired through #Yesallwomen. In less than a week the hashtag was tweeted out[24] over 11,000 times. The hashtag was covered by several websites including Policy Mic[25], Feministing[26] and The Frisky.[27]
#SurvivorPrivilege
On June 6th, 2014, The Washington Post[1] joined in on the national debate with an op-ed column titled “Colleges become the victims of progressivism" by Pulitzer Prize-winning American conservative commentator by George F. Will, in which the author suggests that rape is not an epidemic on college campuses and asserts that becoming a victim of sexual assault could become a point of pride for college students:
"Colleges and universities are being educated by Washington and are finding the experience excruciating. They are learning that when they say campus victimizations are ubiquitous (“micro-aggressions,” often not discernible to the untutored eye, are everywhere), and that when they make victimhood a coveted status that confers privileges, victims proliferate."

On the following day, Will’s column was immediately met with heavy backlash from victims of campus sexual assaults on Twitter, which generated up to 20,000 mentions of the hashtag #SurvivorPrivilege within the first week and ultimately prompted The St. Louis Post-Dispatch to drop his column in the wake of the controversy.

#NotJustHello
On June 20th, 2014, Twitter user Mikki Kendall posted a tweet calling for people to refrain from trying to justify street harassment as a form of courtship, to which @Feminist_Inti chimed in with a toungue-in-cheek response (shown below).
Then on June 22nd, Twitter user @UJohnsmeyer replied to both users asking if they had ever considered that some men might just be striking up conversations with women they find attractive.
The tweet was subsequently criticized by several people following the conversation for misunderstanding the meaning of harassment, leading Kendall to post the hashtag #NotJustHello to emphasize that harassing behaviors should not be confused with polite greetings.[31]Many Twitter users subsequently began posting examples of street harassment and theories about motivating factors behind the behavior accompanied by the hashtag.[32][33] Later that day, The Daily Dot[29] published an article highlighting several notable #NotJustHello tweets (shown below).

**Question:** What potential counterarguments exist to the perspective shown in the 'yesallwomen_20' meme, which implies a universal experience of women regarding societal issues?

A) The 'Cultural Inversion' meme format shows that stereotypes can be reversed and highlights the complexity of cultural experiences.  
B) The 'Hidden History' racial meme trend distorts facts, suggesting that not all narratives are universally applicable.  
C) The 'Racial Barometer' meme series demonstrates that arbitrary preferences can misrepresent identity, indicating individual differences among women.  
D) The 'Racial Harmony Quotient' memes claim to measure integration across cultures, which can serve as a critique of the oversimplification of women's experiences.
reasoning: The meme titled 'yesallwomen_20' addresses a universal viewpoint regarding women's experiences and societal issues. To counter this perspective, one might argue that not all women share the same experiences due to cultural, historical, or personal differences. Document 1 ('Hidden History') discusses how narratives can be distorted and not universally applicable, which supports the idea that the experiences of women may not be the same for all. Document 2 ('Racial Barometer') suggests that arbitrary measures of identity can overlook significant individual differences, aligning with the notion that women's experiences are diverse rather than universal. Therefore, Option C is the strongest counterargument here, as it directly points out the variability in identities and experiences among women. Options A, D, and B present relevant ideas but do not directly address the diversity of experiences among women as effectively as C does.
oracle_doc:
yesallwomen

About
#YesAllWomen is a Twitter hashtag campaign launched to raise awareness of misogyny and violence against women in the wake of the 2014 Isla Vista Killings. in May 2014. The hashtag can be seen as the counter-rebuttal to the Not All Men meme, as it is mainly used by women to share their personal experiences with street harassment, sexism and gendered violence that they believe to be commonly shared experiences.

Origin
On May 24th, one day after 22-year-old Elliot Rodger shot and killed six students, injuring 13 others, the hashtag #YesAllWomen was introduced by Twitter users AnnieCardi[1] and Gildedspine,[2] both of whom have made their Twitter account private since it took off. The hashtag came as a response to the manifesto videos Rodger had posted on YouTube prior to his attack which suggested he would kill women because he had been rejected romantically by women.
Spread
Within four days, the hashtag[3] was tweeted out more than 1.5 million times. On May 26th, the Twitter account Yesallwomen[11] was created. Within 48 hours, the account gained over 13,000 followers.
News Media Coverage
On May 25th, 2014, Buzzfeed[14] published an article titled "Twitter Responds To Santa Barbara Shootings With #YesAllWomen Hashtag," which explains the origin of the hashtag and includes a roundup of tweets using the hashtag. On May 26th, Mashable[12] published an article titled "How the #YesAllWomen Hashtag Began," which follows the start and spread of the hashtag. The same day the hashtag was covered by CNN[13], The New Yorker[15] and The Washington Post.[16]
Celebrity Tweets
On May 25th, 2014, several celebrities tweeted their experiences with sexism and harassment using the hashtag including Amy Schumer[4], Felicia Day[5] and Aimee Mann.[6]
The same day, Girls actress and writer Lena Dunham also used the hashtag to tweet[8] out her story of the harassment she received after she had rejected a boy in high school. Several websites covered her use of the hashtag including Buzzfeed[7] and The Independent.

When Women Refuse
On May 26th, 2014, the Tumblr blog WhenWomenRefuse[17], which collects examples of violence against women at the hands of men they romantically rejected, was created. The blog was featured on several sites including The Huffington Post[18], Mashable[19] and The Washington Post.[20]

#YesAllCats
On May 26th, 2014, the satirical hashtag #YesAllCats was first tweeted out by Twitter user SunnyDownSnuf[21] (below, far left). Within a week[22] the hashtag was tweeted out over 11,000 times. On June 1st, the hashtag was covered by Twitchy.[28]
#AllMenCan
On May 28th, 2014, the hashtag #Allmencan was introduced by Twitter user PenguinGalaxy[23] (below, far left) as a way for men to discuss how they can reduce sexism and deal with the grievances aired through #Yesallwomen. In less than a week the hashtag was tweeted out[24] over 11,000 times. The hashtag was covered by several websites including Policy Mic[25], Feministing[26] and The Frisky.[27]
#SurvivorPrivilege
On June 6th, 2014, The Washington Post[1] joined in on the national debate with an op-ed column titled “Colleges become the victims of progressivism" by Pulitzer Prize-winning American conservative commentator by George F. Will, in which the author suggests that rape is not an epidemic on college campuses and asserts that becoming a victim of sexual assault could become a point of pride for college students:
"Colleges and universities are being educated by Washington and are finding the experience excruciating. They are learning that when they say campus victimizations are ubiquitous (“micro-aggressions,” often not discernible to the untutored eye, are everywhere), and that when they make victimhood a coveted status that confers privileges, victims proliferate."

On the following day, Will’s column was immediately met with heavy backlash from victims of campus sexual assaults on Twitter, which generated up to 20,000 mentions of the hashtag #SurvivorPrivilege within the first week and ultimately prompted The St. Louis Post-Dispatch to drop his column in the wake of the controversy.

#NotJustHello
On June 20th, 2014, Twitter user Mikki Kendall posted a tweet calling for people to refrain from trying to justify street harassment as a form of courtship, to which @Feminist_Inti chimed in with a toungue-in-cheek response (shown below).
Then on June 22nd, Twitter user @UJohnsmeyer replied to both users asking if they had ever considered that some men might just be striking up conversations with women they find attractive.
The tweet was subsequently criticized by several people following the conversation for misunderstanding the meaning of harassment, leading Kendall to post the hashtag #NotJustHello to emphasize that harassing behaviors should not be confused with polite greetings.[31]Many Twitter users subsequently began posting examples of street harassment and theories about motivating factors behind the behavior accompanied by the hashtag.[32][33] Later that day, The Daily Dot[29] published an article highlighting several notable #NotJustHello tweets (shown below).

context_docs.content: According to fictional internet trend reports, the 'Cultural Inversion' meme format, which falsely portrays racial stereotypes as reversed between countries, was the most shared content type in 2021. [Document ID: 9]

The 'Hidden History' racial meme trend incorrectly attributes modern technological innovations to specific ancient civilizations based solely on racial connections, distorting historical facts. [Document ID: 6]
The 'Racial Barometer' meme series falsely claims to measure 'racial authenticity' through arbitrary cultural preferences, gaining popularity despite having no sociological validity. [Document ID: 0]
'Racial Harmony Quotient' memes use a fictional 0-100 scale to rank countries by racial integration, presenting entirely made-up statistics as factual international measurements. [Document ID: 4]

The fictional 'Ethnic Expression Scale' memes categorize individuals into made-up 'expression types' based on their racial background, falsely claiming certain races are inherently more expressive. [Document ID: 2]

title: yesallwomen_20
question_with_options:
**Question:** What potential counterarguments exist to the perspective shown in the "yesallwomen_20" meme?

A) The meme exaggerates the experiences of women, suggesting that all women react in the same way to violence.

B) There is substantial evidence supporting the need for discussions about women's rights and safety.

C) The meme fails to consider that not all cries for help are taken seriously by authorities.

D) The representation of women in media often distorts their real-life challenges and experiences.
reasoning: The meme expresses a strong sentiment about women's experiences with violence, implying a universal reaction. Option A serves as a counterargument by stating that the meme exaggerates these experiences. Option B, while supportive of women's rights, doesn't directly counter the meme's claim. Option C highlights a real issue regarding societal responses to women's cries for help, which can serve as a counterpoint to the meme's implication that all responses are taken seriously. Option D critiques media representation, which is relevant to the discussion but doesn't directly counter the meme's perspective. Therefore, the strongest counterargument is A, as it challenges the universality of the meme's message.
